fields.summary: implement copy alarm on alarm details page

comments.body:
[~jloza]: I noticed the dimensions list for the alarm details page uses the listMetrics() API call to fetch possible resources.  That severely restricts the dimensions to only resources that have CloudWatch data, meaning you won't be able to add a dimension for, say, a volume or ELB that doesn't have CW data.  

However, if we want to expand the available dimensions to all resources (based on the metric choice), that would require numerous API calls (e.g. fetch all volumes, fetch all instances, etc. for the account), which is how we handled that on the old create alarm dialog on the create scaling policy page.  

Guess there's a balancing act here, so please advise whether you want us to 1) continue using listMetrics for populating available dimensions or 2) Use multiple "fetch resources" API calls to offer more flexibility in creating alarms for resources that don't yet have CW data.

hi [~kgill],

Same use case as before that prompted the static metric list, we want to support creating alarms for resources that don't yet have CW data. Thanks!
[~jloza]: Understood... do we need to pull GUI-2197 out of QA to get that fixed on the alarm details page?
Maybe just fix it here, too? whatever you want to do is OK with me
[~jloza]: The metrics landing page has a similar issue w.r.t. using listMetrics() for displaying possible resources, preventing alarms from being created for resources without CloudWatch data.
[~kgill] could be OK for the metrics landing page, that is how AWS works too?

[~jloza]: I don't know how AWS handles it, but not being able to create an alarm for any resource, whether it has CW data or not, from that page (especially as we don't have a create alarm dialog on the alarms landing page) is a significant handicap IMO.

[~kgill] we only show metrics that exist on the metrics landing page AFAIK. I would think that checking every resource to see if it has monitoring enabled, and then displaying metrics for that whether or not CW is yet returning data, would be a major change to the console code, assuming that is what you;d have to do since you can't simply list all resources and all metrics since not all resources have monitoring turned on.  

[~dkavanagh], you built that page, are my assumptions correct? We don't want to display metrics for resources that don't have monitoring enabled. Is there a way to do that that isn't a ton of code, or a possible performance hit?

I am not super concerned with this one thing, as it echoes AWS and so at the very worst if there's not an elegant and performant way to do this we shouldn't until we have customer feedback that they'd like it that way.

Today, we rely on list_metrics (to show us resource reporting metrics) and using a static list instead, means the resources lists we show would need to be filtered based on monitoring enablement, correct. I don't think that if we're already pulling the list of resources, that filtering by monitoring would be much more work in some cases. There are cases, like volume where monitoring is enabled by a setting on the instance it's attached to, so we may require additional info in that case (i.e. it would take more time).

Metrics landing page is not a problem at this time. It should only be showing metrics that exist. If a customer wants to create an alarm for a resource that isn't reporting data yet they can do that from the resource detail page, which is where they would be if they enable monitoring there anyway. No need to add every turnable knob to a GUI just because it's turnable. We should keep things as simple as possible. If we get customer requests for this we can always add it later, but there's no need to change it now.

[~jloza]: Given what we know in EUCA-12185, and looking at StackOverflow posts on creating an alarm for multiple resources (e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21312838/aws-cloudwatch-alarms-to-multiple-ec2-instances) perhaps we should modify our "Create alarm like this" to be more of a "Copy this alarm to more resources" feature, which seems more useful and simplifies the user experience.  Thoughts?
[~kgill] if you look at the wireframe, that is what it is. The only selectable option is resource, and then the user can update the actions.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1889

Looking good! A couple of minor things:
* dialog isn't launching from landing page table or tile view
* dimension is flat text but should be single chosen (will be fixed in GUI-2539)
* metric is combobox but should be flat text
[~jloza]: I've made good progress on the dimension selection in GUI-2539, which also has the fix for the static metric display in the Copy Alarm dialog.

[~jloza]: Please review the Copy Alarm dialog launched from the Alarm details page on the GUI-2539 branch.

Incorporating the Copy Alarm dialog on the alarms landing page is a significant amount of work (which we may back out due to the anticipated performance issues), and I suggest we track that in a separate ticket to avoid holding this one up -- if that's ok perhaps we can change the title of this ticket to 'Implement copy alarm on the alarm details page'?
I've opened GUI-2544 to track incorporating copy alarm on the alarms landing page
Name field should be left blank until resource is selected, then name field should be populated, please. Comment originally left in GUI-2539 but should really be addressed here.
[~jloza]: Are we sure we want the resource shoved into the name, per the comments noted in GUI-2546?

[~jloza]: May I suggest we add a timestamp instead of the resource ID to the alarm name, as the dimensions can easily be changed later on the alarm details page.  The timestamp approach is similar to how we handle generation of IAM policy names in the policy generator, and as alarm items don't have a "created" timestamp, adding a timestamp to the name could be useful IMO.

[~jloza]: And perhaps we should display the dimensions on the alarms landing page (and alarm details page?), which would offset removing the "automatically shove the resource ID into the alarm name" feature that seems so problematic.

[~kgill] we can just leave the name field blank and let them pick one. 

Dimension is on alarm detail page but should be added to landing page I agree. Can you write an improvement ticket in Jira for that so we can do it, please?
[~jloza] : Improvement ticket for incorporating dimensions on the alarms landing page is GUI-2553

[~jloza]: I finally tracked down the issue preventing the 'Copy of ' prefix from being added to the alarm name in the Copy Alarm dialog.  When I modified that to wipe out the alarm name altogether, the alarm name field displays as an invalid (red) state when the dialog opens, which isn't ideal.  Let me know if you want to 1) prepend the alarm name of the alarm to be copied with 'Copy of ' or 2) Wipe out the existing name and accept the initial invalid state.  

I suspect 1 isn't so bad if/when we modify the *create* alarm dialog to not shove the resource ID into the alarm name.  Let me know if you want me to make that change as well here?
[~jloza]: Note that PR 1900 has been merged, so please use the master branch to review the recent Copy Alarm dialog changes

[~kgill], please make the alarm name field blank on copy alarm on initial entry and prevent the validation mechanism from kicking off (that shouldn't be hard, just ensure the cursor is in that field by default and the validation doesn't kick until on blur). 

No changes to alarm create needed.
Discovered issue with the alarm name validation check for unique names.  Opened GUI-2557 to track that
Alarm name update for Copy Alarm dialog are in https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1911

Alarm name validation for required field kicked off while cursor still in field, and did not clear when I started typing. Screenshot attached. 

OSX/Chrome
Alarm name validation issue fixed AFAICT, tested on Chrome 50.0.2661.86 (incognito mode)
Looks great, thanks [~kgill]! UX review passed, ready for code review.
For some reason, the alarmName method was renamed setAlarmName, when it clearly returns an alarm name, just confusing rename.
